title: Transcendental Meditation technique - Wikipedia
cleaned_text: Transcendental Meditation technique (abbreviated as TM) is the technique associated with the practice of [Transcendental Meditation](/wiki/Transcendental_Meditation) developed by the Indian spiritual figure [Maharishi Mahesh Yogi](/wiki/Maharishi_Mahesh_Yogi). The practice involves the use of a private [mantra](/wiki/Mantra), and is practised for 20 minutes twice per day while sitting comfortably with one's eyes closed. [[1]](#cite_note-1) [[2]](#cite_note-Epi06-2) Unlike some other approaches to meditation, TM instruction encourages students not to be alarmed by random thoughts which may arise, but to easily return to the [mantra](/wiki/Mantra) when one becomes aware of this. [[3]](#cite_note-Cazenave-3) Advocates of TM claim that the technique promotes a state of relaxed awareness, stress-relief, creativity, and efficiency, as well as physiological benefits such as reducing the risk of [heart disease](/wiki/Heart_disease) and [high blood pressure](/wiki/High_blood_pressure). [[4]](#cite_note-guardian_heritage-4) The technique is purported to allow practitioners to experience [higher states of consciousness](/wiki/States_of_consciousness). [[5]](#cite_note-5) Advanced courses supplement the TM technique with the [TM-Sidhi program](/wiki/TM-Sidhi_program). The methodological quality of scientific research on the therapeutic benefits of meditation in general is poor, because of the varying theoretical approaches and frequent [confirmation bias](/wiki/Confirmation_bias) in individual studies. [[6]](#cite_note-evid-6) A 2012 [meta-analysis](/wiki/Meta-analysis) published in [Psychological Bulletin](/wiki/Psychological_Bulletin), which reviewed 163 individual studies, found that Transcendental Meditation performed no better overall than other meditation techniques in improving psychological variables. [[7]](#cite_note-Sed12a-7) A 2014 [Cochrane review](/wiki/Cochrane_review) of four trials found that it was impossible to draw any conclusions about whether TM is effective in preventing [cardiovascular disease](/wiki/Cardiovascular_disease), as the scientific literature on TM was limited and at "serious risk of bias". [[8]](#cite_note-8) However, a 2015 systematic review and meta-analysis of 12 studies found that TM may effectively reduce blood pressure compared to [control groups](/wiki/Treatment_and_control_groups). [[9]](#cite_note-9) Practice[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Transcendental_Meditation_technique&action=edit§ion=1)] The technique is recommended for 20 minutes twice per day. [[10]](#cite_note-Craze-10) According to the Maharishi, "bubbles of thought are produced in a stream one after the other", and the Transcendental Meditation technique consists of experiencing a "proper thought" in its more subtle states "until its is experienced and transcended". [[11]](#cite_note-Needleman-11) [[12]](#cite_note-Science_of_Being-12): pp 46-52 Because it is mantra based, the technique "ostensibly meets the working definition of a concentration practice"; however, the TM organisation says that "focused attention" is not prescribed, and that the "aim is a unified and open attentional stance". [[13]](#cite_note-Harvard_Review-13) Other authors describe the technique as an easy, natural technique or process, [[14]](#cite_note-Healing_Depression-14) of the technique includes a process called "unstressing" which combines "effortless relaxation with spontaneous imagery and emotion". TM teachers caution their students not to be alarmed by random thoughts and to "attend" to the mantra. [[3]](#cite_note-Cazenave-3) Scottish chess grandmaster [Jonathan Rowson](/wiki/Jonathan_Rowson) has said that his TM practice gives "a feeling of serenity, energy and balance", but does not provide "any powerful insight into your own mind". Laura Tenant, a reporter for [The Independent](/wiki/The_Independent), said that her TM experience includes going "to a place which was neither wakefulness, sleeping or dreaming", and becoming "detached from my physical self". [[18]](#cite_note-18) Worldwide, four to six million people over the decade 2003 to 2013 have been reported to be practitioners. [[19]](#cite_note-19) Mantra[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Transcendental_Meditation_technique&action=edit§ion=2)] The TM technique consists of silently repeating a [mantra](/wiki/Mantra) with "gentle effortlessness" while sitting comfortably with eyes closed and without assuming any special yoga position. [[15]](#cite_note-Olson-15) [[20]](#cite_note-20) The mantra is said to be a vehicle that allows the individual's attention to travel naturally to a less active, quieter style of mental functioning. [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21): pp 16-20 [[22]](#cite_note-Phelan-22) [[23]](#cite_note-Hunt-23) TM meditators are instructed to keep their mantra secret [[15]](#cite_note-Olson-15) to ensure maximum results, to avoid confusion in the mind of the meditators, [[11]](#cite_note-Needleman-11) and as a reported to have standardised and "mechanized" the mantra selection process by using a specific set of mantras and making the selection process "foolproof". [[11]](#cite_note-Needleman-11) [[26]](#cite_note-Jefferson-26) Professor of psychiatry [Norman E. Rosenthal](/wiki/Norman_E._Rosenthal) writes that during the training given by a certified TM teacher, "each student is assigned a specific mantra or sound, with instructions on its proper use". [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21) The Maharishi said that the selection of a proper thought or mantra "becomes increasingly important when we consider that the power of thought increases when the thought is appreciated in its infant stages of development". [[12]](#cite_note-Science_of_Being-12): p 51 [[27]](#cite_note-27) He said that mantras chosen for initiates should "resonate to the pulse of his thought and as it resonates, create an increasingly soothing influence", [[28]](#cite_note-Religion_in_Amer-28) and that the chosen mantra's vibrations "harmonize" with the meditator and suit his/her "nature way of life". [[29]](#cite_note-29) [[30]](#cite_note-Odd_Gods-30) Author [George D. Chryssides](/wiki/George_D._Chryssides) writes that according to the Maharishi, "using just any mantra can be dangerous"; the mantras for "householders" and for [recluses](/wiki/Recluse) differ. According to Chryssides, many mantras - such as "Om" - commonly found in books are mantras for recluses and "can cause a person to withdraw from life". [[31]](#cite_note-Chryssides-31) [[32]](#cite_note-Chryssides2-32) [[33]](#cite_note-33) Former TM teacher and author Lola Williamson reports that she told her TM students that their mantra was chosen for them based on their personal interview, [[34]](#cite_note-WillismsonInitiation-34) while sociologist [Roy Wallis](/wiki/Roy_Wallis) and religious scholar [J. Gordon Melton](/wiki/J._Gordon_Melton) write that the mantras are assigned and gender. [[35]](#cite_note-Bainbridge-35) published in [Omni](/wiki/Omni_(magazine)) from "disaffected TM teachers". [[43]](#cite_note-43) [[44]](#cite_note-44) According to Chryssides, TM teachers say that the promised results are dependent on a trained Transcendental Meditation teacher choosing the mantra for their student. [[31]](#cite_note-Chryssides-31) Meaning and sound value[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Transcendental_Meditation_technique&action=edit§ion=4)] In his 1963 book The Science of Being and Art of Living, the Maharishi writes that words create waves of vibrations, and the quality of vibration of a mantra should correspond to the vibrational quality of the individual. Likewise, religious studies scholar [Thomas Forsthoefel](/wiki/Thomas_Forsthoefel) writes, "the theory of mantras is the theory of sound". [[45]](#cite_note-Forsthoefel-45) Author William Jefferson writes that the " [euphonics](/wiki/Euphonic)" of mantras are important. [[26]](#cite_note-Jefferson-26) Sociologist [Stephen J. Hunt](/wiki/Stephen_J._Hunt) and others say that the mantra used in the Transcendental Meditation technique "has no meaning", but that "the sound itself" is sacred. [[23]](#cite_note-Hunt-23) [[42]](#cite_note-Barrett-42) In [Kerala](/wiki/Kerala), India, in 1955, the Maharishi spoke of mantras in terms of personal deities, and according to religious studies scholar [Cynthia Ann Humes](/wiki/Cynthia_Ann_Humes), similar references can be found in his later works. [[45]](#cite_note-Forsthoefel-45): p 63 [[46]](#cite_note-Beacon-46) According to authors Peter Russell and [Norman Rosenthal](/wiki/Norman_Rosenthal), the sounds used in the technique are taken from the ancient [Vedic](/wiki/Vedic) tradition, have "no specific meaning", [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21) [[47]](#cite_note-Russell1-47): pp 49-50 and are selected for their suitability for the individual. [[48]](#cite_note-Phelan,_Michael_1979-48) Nevertheless, the Maharishi mentions that sometimes it is beneficial for the Mantra to be associated with a specific meaning in order to suit one's own private psychological background. [[49]](#cite_note-:0-49) Author Lola Williamson writes that the bija, or seed mantras, used in TM come from the [Tantric](/wiki/Tantra), rather than Vedic tradition, and that bija mantras are "traditionally associated with particular deities and used as a form of worship". [[50]](#cite_note-50) [[51]](#cite_note-Mangalwadi-51) According to Needleman, many mantras come from the Vedas or Vedic hymns, which are "the root for all later Hindu scripture", [[11]](#cite_note-Needleman-11) while the 1977 court case Malnak vs. Yogi accepted the TM mantras as meaningless sounds. [[52]](#cite_note-52) Likewise, philosophy of science scholar and former [Maharishi International University](/wiki/Maharishi_International_University) professor Jonathan Shear writes in his book The Experience of Meditation: Experts Introduce the Major Traditions that the mantras used in the TM technique are independent of meaning associated with any [language](/wiki/Language), and are used for their mental sound value alone. [[53]](#cite_note-Shear-53) Fred Travis of the [Maharishi University of Management](/wiki/Maharishi_University_of_Management) writes in a 2009 article published in the International Journal of Psychophysiology that "unlike most mantra meditations, any possible meaning of the mantra is not part of Transcendental Meditation practice". [[54]](#cite_note-psychophysiology1-54) Courses[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Transcendental_Meditation_technique&action=edit§ion=5)] The Transcendental Meditation technique is taught in a standardised seven-step course over six days by a certified TM [[55]](#cite_note-Total_Heart_Health-55): 148-149 [[15]](#cite_note-Olson-15) [[47]](#cite_note-Russell1-47): p 134 [[56]](#cite_note-The_Seven-Step_Course-56) [[57]](#cite_note-TM_Crime-57) [[58]](#cite_note-58) Except for a requirement to refrain from using non-prescription drugs for 15 days before learning TM, [[11]](#cite_note-Needleman-11) [[59]](#cite_note-59) all who want to learn are taught provided they can pay the course fee which as of 2023 [[update]](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Transcendental_Meditation_technique&action=edit), ranges from $420 for students to $980 for members of households with incomes of $200,000 or more. [[60]](#cite_note-60) The technique is taught via private and group instruction by a TM teacher trained to instruct students and provide follow up. [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21) Instruction is given on separate days, beginning with a one-hour "introductory lecture" intended to prepare the student for subsequent steps. [[15]](#cite_note-Olson-15) The lecture discusses mind potential, social relationships, health, and "promoting inner and outer peace". The second step is a 45-minute "preparatory lecture", whose topic is the theory of the practice, its origins and its relationship to other types of meditation. [[15]](#cite_note-Olson-15) [[57]](#cite_note-TM_Crime-57) [[61]](#cite_note-TM.org-61) This is followed by the third step: a private, ten-minute, personal interview, allowing the TM teacher to get acquainted with the student and answer questions. [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21) [[57]](#cite_note-TM_Crime-57) [[62]](#cite_note-Ospina2007-62) According to the TM web site, the personal instruction session takes 1-2 hours, [[61]](#cite_note-TM.org-61) and students are required to bring a clean handkerchief, some flowers and fruit, and their course fee. [[35]](#cite_note-Bainbridge-35) The initiation begins with a short [puja](/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)) ceremony performed by the teacher. The stated purpose of the ceremony is to show honour and gratitude to the lineage of TM "masters", [[35]](#cite_note-Bainbridge-35) [[63]](#cite_note-63) or "Holy Tradition" [[64]](#cite_note-Johnson-64) that is listed the Maharishi's translation and commentary of the Bhagavad-Gita. [[65]](#cite_note-65) It is regarded as putting students in the right frame of mind to receive the mantra. [[34]](#cite_note-WillismsonInitiation-34) The ceremony is conducted in a private room with a "little" white altar containing incense, camphor, rice, flowers and a picture of Maharishi's teacher, Guru Dev. [[34]](#cite_note-WillismsonInitiation-34) [[66]](#cite_note-Victory-66) The initiate observes passively as the teacher recites a text in [Sanskrit](/wiki/Sanskrit). [[64]](#cite_note-Johnson-64) After the ceremony, the "meditators" are "invited to bow", receive their mantra and begin to meditate. [[30]](#cite_note-Odd_Gods-30) [[34]](#cite_note-WillismsonInitiation-34) [[66]](#cite_note-Victory-66) [[67]](#cite_note-67) On the day after the personal instruction session, the student begins a series of three 90-to-120-minute "teaching sessions", held on three consecutive days, called "three days of checking". [[55]](#cite_note-Total_Heart_Health-55) [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21) Their stated purpose is to "verify the correctness of the practice" and to receive further instruction. [[61]](#cite_note-TM.org-61) The first day's checking meeting takes place in a group on the day following personal instruction, and gives information about correct practice based on each student's own experience. [[57]](#cite_note-TM_Crime-57) The second day of checking uses the same group format, and gives more details of the mechanics of the practice and potential results of the practice, based on student experiences. [[57]](#cite_note-TM_Crime-57) The third day of checking focuses on subjective growth and the potential development of higher stages of human [consciousness](/wiki/Consciousness), and outlines the follow-up programs available as part of the course. [[68]](#cite_note-google138-68) [[55]](#cite_note-Total_Heart_Health-55) [[69]](#cite_note-69) [[70]](#cite_note-70) New meditators later return for private follow-up sessions to confirm that they are practising the technique properly, a process called "personal checking". [[11]](#cite_note-Needleman-11) The preferred schedule for follow-up classes is 30 minutes, once per week for one month, and once per month thereafter. The purpose of the follow-up, or "checking sessions", is to verify the practice, give an opportunity for one-on-one contact with a TM teacher, and to address any problems or questions. [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21) [[62]](#cite_note-Ospina2007-62) Course graduates may access a lifetime follow-up program which includes consultations, "refresher courses", advanced lectures and group meditations. [[71]](#cite_note-71) [[72]](#cite_note-72) Advanced courses include weekend Residence Courses and the TM-Sidhi program. According to the TM organisation, TM course fees cover "initial training and the lifetime follow-up" program, while helping to "build and maintain TM centers" and schools in India and around the world. [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21): 9 [[73]](#cite_note-73) The fees also reportedly provide TM scholarships for special-needs groups, as well as grants and scholarships through TM's Maharishi Foundation, a government-approved [501(c)(3)](/wiki/501(c)(3)) non-profit, educational organisation. [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21): p 9 [[61]](#cite_note-TM.org-61) The fees may "vary from country to country", depending on the cost of living, [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21): pp 9, 216 and have changed periodically during the 50-year period that the course has been taught. The Maharishi has drawn criticism from yogis and "stricter Hindus" who have accused him of selling "commercial mantras". [[74]](#cite_note-74) At the same time, the Maharishi's "promises of better health, stress relief and spiritual enlightenment" have drawn "devotees from all over the world", despite the fees. [[75]](#cite_note-75) [[76]](#cite_note-76) [[77]](#cite_note-77) According to The Complete Idiot's Guide to World Religions, by Brandon Toropov and Father Luke Buckles, insistence on fees for TM instruction has caused critics to question the Maharishi's motives; however, "the movement is not, one". [[78]](#cite_note-78) TM-Sidhi program[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Transcendental_Meditation_technique&action=edit§ion=6)] The TM-Sidhi form of meditation introduced by Maharishi Mahesh Yogi in 1975. It is based on, and described as a natural extension of the Transcendental Meditation technique. [[79]](#cite_note-79) [[80]](#cite_note-80) The goal of the TM-Sidhi program is to accelerate personal growth and improve mind-body coordination [[81]](#cite_note-MPTCWP-81) by training the mind to think from what the Maharishi has described as a fourth major state of consciousness [[82]](#cite_note-82) called Transcendental Consciousness. [[83]](#cite_note-lighthouse-83) Yogic Flying, a mental-physical exercise of hopping while cross-legged, [[84]](#cite_note-84) [[85]](#cite_note-85) is a central aspect of the TM-Sidhi program. With the introduction of the TM-Sidhi program in 1976, it was postulated that a group of people practising the TM-Sidhi program twice a day, together in one place, would increase "life-supporting trends" in the surroundings, with the threshold for the group size being the square root of 1% of the area's population. This was called the "Extended Maharishi Effect", referring to the "Maharishi effect" with a threshold of 1% of the population. [[86]](#cite_note-Karam-86) [[87]](#cite_note-Maharishi_University_of_Management-87) These effects have been examined in 14 published studies, including a gathering of over 4,000 people in Washington DC in the summer of 1993. [[86]](#cite_note-Karam-86) [[88]](#cite_note-88) While empirical studies have been published in peer-reviewed academic journals [[89]](#cite_note-89) this research remains controversial and has characterised as began training TM teachers in the early 1960s, [[92]](#cite_note-92) and by 1978, there were 7,000 TM teachers in the United States. [[93]](#cite_note-93) In 1985, there were an estimated 10,000 TM teachers worldwide, [[94]](#cite_note-94) and by 2003, there were 20,000 teachers, [[95]](#cite_note-95) and a reported 40,000 teachers in 2008. [[96]](#cite_note-96) Notable individuals trained to teach the Transcendental first teacher training course was held in India with 30 participants in 1967 and 200 participants in 1970. [[101]](#cite_note-Russell-101) A four-month teacher training course was also held in the United States that year. The first part was four weeks long and was offered in both [Poland, Maine](/wiki/Poland,_Maine) and [Humboldt, California](/wiki/Humboldt_County,_California) with the final three months being held in [Estes Park, Colorado](/wiki/Estes_Park,_Colorado). About 300 people completed the training. [[102]](#cite_note-Goldberg-102) In 1973, the TM teacher training course consisted of three months in-residence. [[103]](#cite_note-103) A 2007 TM web page and 2009 book, report that the TM teacher training course in more modern times consists of six months in-residence, [[14]](#cite_note-Healing_Depression-14) and includes courses in Maharishi Vedic Science, extended meditation practice and becoming the "custodian" for an "ancient Vedic tradition". Additionally, TM teachers are trained to speak on the Transcendental Meditation program, teach it to others, provide "personal checking" of their students' meditation, create lectures on related topics, organise and lead advanced TM courses and programs. [[104]](#cite_note-104) The Maharishi trained his teachers to "make logical presentations in language suitable to their audiences", and teachers lead their students through a sequence of predetermined steps. [[102]](#cite_note-Goldberg-102) A 2007 research study reported that details of the training and knowledge imparted to teachers are kept private. [[62]](#cite_note-Ospina2007-62) In 1976, Janis Johnson wrote in [The Christian Century](/wiki/The_Christian_Century) that TM teachers sign a "loyalty-oath employment contract", saying "It is my fortune, Guru Dev, that I have been accepted to serve the Holy Tradition and spread the Light of God to all those who need it." [[64]](#cite_note-Johnson-64) [[105]](#cite_note-105) Author William Bainbridge writes that a section of a training bulletin for TM teachers called "Explanations of the Invocation" draws a "connection to Brahma, the Lord of Creation". [[35]](#cite_note-Bainbridge-35) A 1993 article in the [Ottawa Citizen](/wiki/Ottawa_Citizen) reported a partial translation of the puja as "Whosoever remembers the lotus-eyed Lord gains inner and outer purity. To Lord [Naryan](/wiki/Narayana), to Lotus-born Brahman the creator, to [Vaishistha](/wiki/Vasistha), to [Shakti](/wiki/Shakti), to [Shankaracharya](/wiki/Shankaracharya) the emancipator, hailed as [Krishna](/wiki/Krishna), to the Lord I bow down and down again. At whose door the whole galaxy of gods pray for perfection day and night". [[106]](#cite_note-Harvey1993-106) Research[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Transcendental_Meditation_technique&action=edit§ion=8)] Scientists have been conducting research on meditation, including TM, since the late 1960s and hundreds of studies have been published. [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21): 14 [[107]](#cite_note-107) [[108]](#cite_note-108) Transcendental Meditation has become one of the most widely researched meditation techniques. [[109]](#cite_note-Bushell-109) [[110]](#cite_note-Freeman2009-110) TM research has played a role in the history of mind-body medicine [[111]](#cite_note-111) [[112]](#cite_note-112) and encouraged [neuroscience](/wiki/Neuroscience) research focusing on the effects of meditation. [[113]](#cite_note-113) Early studies examined the physiological parameters of meditation. Subsequent research included clinical applications, cognitive effects, mental health, medical costs, and rehabilitation. Beginning in the 1990s, research focused on cardiovascular disease. [[114]](#cite_note-QUICK-114) Research reviews of the effects of the Transcendental Meditation technique have yielded results ranging from inconclusive [[115]](#cite_note-Ospina-115) [[123]](#cite_note-Integrative_Cardiology-123) More research is needed to determine the therapeutic effects of meditation practices and sources vary regarding their assessment of the quality of research. Some cite design limitations and a lack of [methodological rigour](/wiki/Scientific_method), [[62]](#cite_note-Ospina2007-62) [[116]](#cite_note-Cochrane06-116) [[124]](#cite_note-124) while others assert that the quality is improving and that when suitable assessment criteria are applied, scientific evidence supports the therapeutic value of meditation. [[125]](#cite_note-125) [[126]](#cite_note-126) [[127]](#cite_note-127) Reviewers Canter and Ernst assert that some studies have the potential for bias due to the connection of researchers to the TM organisation [[128]](#cite_note-128) [[129]](#cite_note-129) while TM researchers point to their collaboration with independent researchers and universities as signs of objectivity. [[130]](#cite_note-130) Institutional programs[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Transcendental_Meditation_technique&action=edit§ion=9)] In schools and universities[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Transcendental_Meditation_technique&action=edit§ion=10)] Transcendental Meditation in education (also known as Consciousness-Based Education) is the application of the Transcendental Meditation technique in an educational setting or institution. These educational programs and institutions have been founded in the United States, United Kingdom, Australia, India, Africa and Japan. The Transcendental Meditation technique became popular with students in the 1960s and by the early 1970s centers for the Students International Meditation Society were established at a thousand campuses [[131]](#cite_note-Olson-Encyclopedia-131) in the United States with similar growth occurring in Germany, Canada and Britain. [[35]](#cite_note-Bainbridge-35): p 188 The [Maharishi International University](/wiki/Maharishi_University_of_Management) was established in 1973 in the United States and began offering accredited degree programs. In 1977 courses in Transcendental Meditation and the Science of Creative Intelligence (SCI) were banned from New Jersey public high schools on religious grounds by virtue of the [Establishment Clause](/wiki/Establishment_Clause) of the [First Amendment](/wiki/First_Amendment). [[132]](#cite_note-conlaw-132) [[133]](#cite_note-malnak-133) This "dismantled" the TM program's use government funding in US public schools [[45]](#cite_note-Forsthoefel-45): pp 63-66 but "did not constitute a negative evaluation of the program itself". [[134]](#cite_note-134) Since 1979, schools that incorporate the Transcendental Meditation technique using private, non-governmental funding have been reported in the United States, South America, Southeast Asia, Northern Ireland, South Africa and Israel. [[135]](#cite_note-135) [[136]](#cite_note-136) [[137]](#cite_note-137) A number of educational institutions have by [Maharishi Mahesh Yogi](/wiki/Maharishi_Mahesh_Yogi), the [Transcendental Meditation movement](/wiki/Transcendental_Meditation_movement) and its supporters. These institutions include several schools offering public and private secondary education in the United States ( [Maharishi School of the Mandir Schools](/wiki/Maharishi_Vidya_Mandir_Schools)). Likewise, Maharishi colleges and universities been established including [Maharishi European Research University](/wiki/Maharishi_European_Research_University) (Netherlands), [Maharishi Institute of Management](/wiki/Maharishi_Institute_of_Management) (India), [Maharishi University of Management and Technology](/wiki/Maharishi_University_of_Management_and_Technology) (India), Maharishi [[145]](#cite_note-145) [[146]](#cite_note-146) and [Maharishi Mahesh Yogi University](/wiki/Maharishi_Mahesh_Yogi_Vedic_University) (India). According to an article in [Newsweek](/wiki/Newsweek), "critics believe that TM is a repackaged form of Eastern religious philosophy" and opposed its use in public schools [[147]](#cite_note-Conant-147) [[148]](#cite_note-Williamson-148) while a member of the [Pacific Justice Institute](/wiki/Pacific_Justice_Institute) says practising Transcendental Meditation in public schools with private funding is constitutional. [[149]](#cite_note-Conant2008-05-29-149) Corporate programs[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Transcendental_Meditation_technique&action=edit§ion=11)] Transcendental Meditation has been utilised in corporations, both in the United States and in India, under the auspices of the [International Foundation for the Science of Creative Intelligence](/wiki/Transcendental_Meditation_movement#1970:_International_Foundation_for_the_Science_of_Creative_Intelligence) and the Maharishi Development Corporation. As of 2001, US companies such as [General Motors](/wiki/General_Motors) and [IBM](/wiki/IBM) were subsidising the TM course fee for their employees. [[150]](#cite_note-150) A number of Indian companies provide the TM technique to their managers. These companies The Sunday Times Herald reports that there are more than 100 Japanese companies where TM was introduced at induction. [[152]](#cite_note-152) Social programs[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Transcendental_Meditation_technique&action=edit§ion=12)] The TM technique has been incorporated in US social programs for criminals, the homeless and war veterans. In 1979, it was offered to inmates at [Folsom prison](/wiki/Folsom_prison), [San Quentin](/wiki/San_Quentin) and the [Deuel Vocational Institute](/wiki/Deuel_Vocational_Institute). According to a TM representative, meditation has been included at "over 25 prisons and correctional institutions" in the United States. [[153]](#cite_note-153) In [Senegal](/wiki/Senegal), more than 11,000 prisoners and 900 correctional officers in 34 prisons received instruction in TM between 1985 and 1987, and the wardens at 31 prisons signed a proclamation recommending that TM be offered throughout the entire system. [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21): pp 193-195 [[154]](#cite_note-154) More recently, the TM technique has been introduced to prisoners in the Oregon Correctional System and a research study is underway to record the effects of the program. [[21]](#cite_note-Rosenthal-21) Since the late 1980s the TM technique has been offered as part of the programs at Fundacion Hogares Claret sanctuary for homeless and orphaned children in [Medellin](/wiki/Medellin), Colombia. [[155]](#cite_note-155) In 1996, several judges of the 22nd Judicial Circuit of [St Louis](/wiki/St_Louis), [Missouri](/wiki/Missouri), began ordering convicted felons to attend a TM course as one of their conditions for parole. [[156]](#cite_note-Melting_Point-156) The program was administered by the non-profit Enlightened Sentencing Project and received endorsements from federal judge [Henry Autrey](/wiki/Henry_Autrey) and other members of the Missouri district, federal, and supreme courts.
